content.value: Annas Ortsgruppe trifft sich einmal pro Woche. Neben den Spiele- und Bildungsabenden, gibt es regelmäßige Gesangsrunden, in denen die Kinder gemeinsam mit den Helfer*innen Lieder singen. Dazu gehören Lieder wie 'Vorwärts ihr Frauen' oder 'Im blauen Hemd'. Letzteres ist die Hymne der Roten Falken.
Als Rote Falken werden alle 12- bis 14-Jährigen im Verband der Kinderfreunde genannt.
Anna ist stolz, ein 'Roter Falke' zu sein und ein blaues Hemd zu tragen. Endlich hat sie einen Ort gefunden, wo sie sich zugehörig und verstanden fühlt.

Um noch mehr Mitglieder zu gewinnen, hat die Ortsgruppe der Kinderfreunde eine kleine Ausstellung vorbereitet. Die Roten Falken haben dafür Wandzeitungen gestaltet, gebastelt, Wimpel genäht und einige Gebrauchsgegenstände angefertigt.

Die Ausstellung kann gegen einen Eintritt von 10 Pfennig besucht werden. Neben einigen Leuten von der örtlichen Presse kommen auch viele Eltern vorbei. Einige der Ausstellungsobjekte spendet die Ortsgruppe der Arbeiterwohlfahrt.

content.value: Gerda hat noch nie die Aktivitäten einer Kindergruppe organisiert. Um ihre Aufgaben besser zu kennen liest sie das Buch 'Im Zeltlager - ein technisches Handbuch für rote Falkenführer von Hermann Neddermayer. Das Buch wurde gerade erst herausgegeben und sammelt wertvolle Erfahrungen aus den bisherigen Zeltlagern der Kinderfreunde.

Gerda liest wissbegierig die pädagogischen Überlegungen. Daneben finden sich auch praktische Hinweise zur Gestaltung des Zeltdorfes, zur Struktur des Lagerparlamentes und zu den organisatorischen Abläufen in der 'Kinderrepublik'. Die Helfer*innen spielen dabei eine unterstützende, aber keine leitende Rolle.

In Leipzig wird für die Helfer*innen eine Schulungsreihe angeboten. Gerda kann sich so mit der sozialistischen Pädagogik der Kinderfreunde vertraut machen, denn vieles ist ihr neu. Sie nimmt an einem Wochenendkurs unter dem Titel 'Psychologie und sozialistische Pädagogik als Grundlage unserer Jugendarbeit' teil. Dieser wird von Dr. Kurt Löwenstein, dem Vorsitzenden der Reichsarbeitsgemeinschaft der Kinderfreunde, geleitet.

content.value: Um sich praktisch zu bilden, nimmt Gerda zusätzlich an einer Schulung 'Methoden der Hordenarbeit' teil. Auch das 'Soziale Wandern' ist solch eine Methode, die in den Gruppen (auch 'Horden' genannt) oft genutzt wird. Dabei bildet das Wandern eine Möglichkeit, die Welt und fremde Gegenden zu erkunden und gleichzeitig die Lebens- und Wirtschaftsumstände der Menschen zu analysieren.
Gerda sieht darin eine tiefgreifende Auseinandersetzung mit einem anderen Ort. Diese Methode wird sich daher auch gut für die Kinderrepublik eignen.

Der Verband hat Schwierigkeiten, insbesondere jugendliche Helfer*innen zu finden, die länger freiwillig mitarbeiten. Oft helfen sie nur einige Zeit und haben dann wichtigere Dinge zu tun. Daher organisiert der Verband regelmäßig Aktivitäten ausschließlich für die Helfer*innen, damit diese sich kennenlernen und neben den verantwortlichen Aufgaben auch den Zusammenhalt in der Gruppe der Helfer*innen erleben.

Gerda nimmt an einer Wanderung teil, zu der alle Helfer*innen aus ihrer Stadt eingeladen sind. Am Ende sind sie immerhin 16 Jugendliche, die alle zwischen 15 und 18 Jahre alt sind. Einer dieser Kirchenvertreter ist ein katholischer Priester aus der nahen Umgebung. Insbesondere die katholische Kirche lehnt das Prinzip der Koedukation, das die Kinderfreunde  propagieren, ab. Koedukation bedeutet, dass Mädchen und Jungen gemeinsam in der Gruppe aktiv sind. Vor allem die gemeinsam genutzten Zelte hält der Priester für moralisch verwerflich.

In der Hinwendung der Kinder zum Sozialismus sieht er dabei ebenso einen Kampf gegen religiöse Erziehung, als auch eine 'geistige Zertrümmerung der Familie'. Die Kinderfreunde engagieren sich auch für einen Sexualkundeunterricht. Das halten sie für wichtig, da bis weit ins 20. Jahrhundert hinein Erwachsene durch eine falsch verstandene religiöse Sexualmoral keine Ahnung hatten, wie Kinder entstanden.

Vieles, was die Kinderfreunde ausprobierten, war für die Gesellschaft neu. Die Idee einer besseren Welt, in der auch Arbeiterkinder Chancen und eine Zukunft haben sollten, machte manchmal eben auch jenen Angst, die zuvor jahrhundertelang in Machtpositionen waren. Dazu gehörte u.a. die Kirche, aber auch der beispielsweise der Adel.

08.08.
Um 7.00 Uhr erscholl der Weckruf. Darauf klopften wir unsere Decken aus. Als wir damit fertig waren, wurde zur Gymnastik geblasen. Kurz darauf gingen wir zum Waschen. Nach dem Waschen frühstückten wir. Danach setzten wir unser Zelt instand. Zwischen 12.00 und 13.00 Uhr war Falkenvollversammlung. Der neue Lagerleiter hatte verschiedene Themen zu verhandeln, z.B.: der Besuchstag. Wir hatten nämlich Kindertag, da hatten die Helfer nichts zu sagen. Die mussten nachher auf Wanderung. Um 13.30 Uhr bekamen wir Mittagessen. Es gab nämlich Salzkartoffeln mit Rollmops. Nach dem Essen hatten wir Freizeit. Um 15.30 Uhr gab es Vesper. Nach der Vesper war Zirkus. Um 19.00 Uhr wurde zum Abendbrot geblasen. Darauf war Volkstanz. Auf einmal war auf der Straße ein Krach losgegangen. Es kamen nämlich Helfer von der Wanderung zurück. Die sollten nicht vor 12.00 Uhr ins Lager. Hermann Neddermeyer blies Lagerruhe, aber es wurde dagegen protestiert. Hermann erzählte von der Flucht aus England. Bald war Zeltruhe. Kaum lagen wir im Zelte, so wurde Helferalarm geblasen.
Freundschaft.
Irma

Wir wurden heute morgen durch das Spielen des Radios geweckt. Gleich darauf kam Ernst, unser Bürgermeister und brachte die Parole. Nach einer Weile standen wir auf, denn es hatte zum Aufstehen geblasen. Schnell schüttelten wir unsere Decken aus. Dann gingen wir zum Waschen. Nach dem Kaffeetrinken bleiben wir wieder im Zelt, denn es regnete. Heinz sagte uns, dass wir unsere Affen packen sollten, denn es könnte sein, dass wir heute noch ins Notquartier ziehen würden. Unser Lagerpräsident ist schon in die Stadt gegangen und fragt nach, ob wir einige Schulen für das Notquartier bekommen könnten. So packten wir den Vormittag unsere Taschen, um zum Abmarsch bereit zu sein.Bald gab es auch Mittagessen. Das Wetter wurde jetzt schon besser. Am Abend war noch eine Helfersitzung. Dort wurde nun alles besprochen. Es kam nun heraus, dass wir heute nicht mehr wegzogen. Wenn es aber regnet, wollten wir ins Notquartier ziehen. Am Abend spielten wir noch im Kreis. Nach der Lagerruhe schliefen wir bald ein.
Freundschaft.
Georg

content.value: Der wichtigste Punkt für die Falken ist das Bekenntnis zur Arbeiterklasse und zu einer sozialistischen Gesellschaft.

Damit sahen sich die Kinderfreunde genauso wie die SPD und die KPD einer erstarkenden politischen Bewegung gegenüber: die Nationalsozialistische Deutsche Arbeiterpartei (NSDAP) bemühte sich nämlich ebenso um die Arbeiterschaft.

Im Gegensatz zum Sozialismus stand der Nationalsozialismus aber nicht für ein friedliches Zusammenleben aller Menschen, sondern für Rassismus und Ausgrenzung von Menschen vor allem jüdischen Glaubens und die Stärkung der sogenannten Volksgemeinschaft. Auf diese Weise förderte der Nationalsozialismus den Krieg zwischen unterschiedlichen Ländern.
Seit 1926 gab es mit der Hitlerjugend bereits eine Jugendorganisation der NSDAP, die für Kinder ähnlich attraktiv wirkte, wie die sozialistischen und sozialdemokratischen Verbände.

Ausflüge und die Arbeitsgruppen finden meist vor dem Mittagessen statt. Die ruhigeren Nachmittage können die Kinder selbst füllen. Viele verbringen die Zeit dann mit Lesen und Briefeschreiben.
Es müssen in dieser Zeit aber auch manchmal Gruppenangelegenheiten geklärt werden.
An manchen Nachmittagen tanzt das ganze Zeltlager, es gibt Zirkusaufführungen oder Theaterinszenierungen der Kinder und Helfer*innen.

Beide lesen aber auch gern Romane, die von Entdeckungsreisen und fantastischen Orten handeln. Karl hat bisher während des Zeltlagers schon zwei Bücher von Jules Verne gelesen.

Auch einige sehr neue Romane finden sich in der Lagerbücherei. Anna hat zum Beispiel 'Emil und die Detektive' von Erich Kästner gelesen und war begeistert.

Es gibt aber auch Literatur, welche die geistige und moralische Haltung der Kinder stärken soll. Neben wichtigen Werken sozialistischer Autor*innen steht daher auch hochaktuelle Antikriegsliteratur, z.B. 'Im Westen nichts Neues' von Erich Maria Remarque.

Anna und Karl haben nicht nur ähnliche Interessen, sondern wohnen zufällig auch in dem selbem Zeltdorf. Dadurch verbringen sie inzwischen viel Zeit miteinander. Durch Anna und ihre Rolle als Zeltobfrau interessiert sich Karl jetzt auch mehr für die parlamentarische Arbeit in der Kinderrepublik.

content.value: In Annas und Karls Zeltdorf haben sich mehrere Kinder zusammengefunden, die einen Antrag an das Lagerparlament stellen wollen. Sie wollen erreichen, dass die Gymnastik morgens nach dem Frühstück und nicht davor stattfindet.
2_8_Mädchen_in_Turnkleidung_am_Strand
Nachdem sie die Mehrheit für diesen Vorschlag in ihrer Zeltgemeinschaft erhalten haben, reichen sie den Antrag an die Gemeindevertretung des Zeltdorfes weiter.

Die Gemeindevertretung besteht aus 15 Kindern sowie dem Bürgermeister. Der Bürgermeister gibt vor der Abstimmung zu bedenken, dass Sport mit vollem Bauch ungesund ist. Trotzdem stimmt die Mehrheit der Gemeindevertretung dem Antrag zu, denn den Kindern dauert die Zeit bis zum Frühstück oft zu lang.

Der Bürgermeister muss nun den Antrag an das Lagerparlament weiterreichen, sodass alle Vertreter*innen der Gemeinderäte darüber beraten und abstimmen können. Am Ende lehnt das Lagerparlament mit großer Mehrheit den Vorschlag ab.
2_8_Junge_mit_Becher
Es begründet seine Entscheidung damit, dass der Küchendienst nach dem Aufstehen etwas Zeit braucht, um das Essen vorzubereiten und damit, dass Sport vor dem Essen gesünder sei als direkt danach.

Anna hat eingesehen, dass der Ablauf wirklich kompliziert ist. Um die ganze Lagerstruktur besser erklären zu können,  hat sie sich ein Spiel ausgedacht. Sie spielt es mit Karl, um auszuprobieren, ob es verständlich ist.
In diesem Aufdeck-Spiel geht es darum, gleiche Paare zu finden. Klicke einfach auf die Kärtchen, um zu sehen, was sich auf der Rückseite befindet. Zusammenpassende Paare bleiben aufgedeckt liegen.
Wenn du das Spiel gewinnst, wird sich die Kinderrepublik langsam dem Ende nähern.

content.value: Gerda hat den beiden Kindern beim Spielen zugeschaut und findet Annas Idee großartig. Sie will das Spiel mit ihrer Ortsgruppe ausprobieren, wenn sie sich auf das nächste Zeltlager vorbereiten.

Da Gerda nur wenige Jahre älter als Anna und Karl ist, hat sie direkt einen guten Draht zu den beiden. Sie hören ihr gespannt zu, wie sie berichtet, wie sie zur Sozialistischen Arbeiterjugend gekommen ist und warum sie Helferin in der Kinderrepublik geworden ist.
Vielleicht haben Anna und Karl in ein paar Jahren ja auch Lust, als Helfer*in eine Kinderrepublik zu unterstützen. Genügend Erfahrungen gesammelt haben sie immerhin schon.
28_Deutschfranzösisches_Zeltlager

Bis dahin nehmen sie sich jedoch vor, an einem der nächsten Arbeiterjugendtage teilzunehmen. Dieser findet alle ein bis zwei Jahre statt und wird voraussichtlich 1931 in Frankfurt am Main ausgetragen.
Dort treffen sich Arbeiterkinder aus der ganzen Republik, bekunden ihre Solidarität und schmieden Pläne für eine bessere Zukunft.
Die Kinderrepublik nähert sich langsam dem Ende. Für Anna und Karl ist diese Zeit wie im Flug vergangen.
Sie haben viele neue Freund*innen gefunden. Viele davon werden, wie die beiden, bald eine Lehre in einer der großen Fabriken anfangen.
Anna und Karl hoffen, dass sie sich vielleicht Briefe schreiben werden, falls sie nach der Arbeit dann noch Zeit und Kraft dafür finden werden. Auch mit Gerda wollen sie sich gern schreiben.

content.value: One day the doorbell rings. Anna opens and in front of the door are two young people who look only a few years older than her. Their names are Erna and Hans. The two are telling her that they are involved in an association called the 'National working-group of the Friends of the Children'. They are looking for new members for the local group of the association.
Karl sometimes listens to his brothers discussing politics. They explain to him the connections between the state, democracy, work and the living conditions of their family.

Gerda has been attending events of the Socialist Workers' Youth for some time. Now, however, a large democratic and mainly self-organised tent camp of the 'Friends of the Children' is going to take place during the summer.
daheim_werbung

Anna is listening to them with great interest. She learns that the association takes care of the working-class children. The local group is mainly organised by the children and young people themselves and organises game afternoons, tent camps and lectures. She is curious and promises the two of them to stop by tomorrow.
They also tell him about the association of which they are members: the Socialist Workers' Youth.

Karl is still too young for this group, but there is also a socialist association for children: the 'Friends of the Children', who also have a local group close by. Karl wants to to pay them a visit, because there is a lot going on in the local group of the 'Friends of the Children'. There are game afternoons, tent camps and also theme afternoons.

The Friends of the Children are close to the Socialist Workers' Youth and take care of the younger ones. Gerda has little time, but she would like to help other working-class children to experience a distraction from their dreary everyday life. That's why she volunteers to help organise and run the tent camp. It should be called a Children's Republic and offer space for thousands of children from all over the Weimar Republic.

The helpers are volunteering in different local groups and accompanying the children in their preparations for the tent camp. The older and more experienced helpers organise the tickets, the necessary tent material as well as the overnight stays with comrades on the way to the Children's Republic.

chapters.name: The Activities of the Local Group

content.value: Anna's local group meets once a week. In addition to the games and educational evenings, there are regular singing rounds in which the children sing songs together with the helpers. These include songs like 'Vorwärts ihr Frauen' ('Onwards you women') or 'Im blauen Hemd' ('In the blue shirt'). The latter is the anthem of the Red Falcons.
All 12 to 14 year-olds are named as Red Falcons in the association of the Friends of the Children.
Anna is proud to be a Red Falcon and to wear a blue shirt. She has finally found a place where she feels she belongs and is being understood.

To attract even more members, the local group of the Friends of the Children has prepared a small exhibition. The Red Falcons have designed wall newspapers, made handicrafts, sewed pennants and made some articles of daily use.

The exhibition can be visited for an entrance fee of 10 Pfennig. Apart from some people from the local press, many parents come along. Some of the exhibits are donated by the local group of the Worker's Welfare Union.

groups.info: A 'class' refers to a group of people who have common social/economic interests and living conditions.

content.value: The educational evenings deal with both political and practical topics, such as hygiene.

Anna learns during a lecture that the misery of the working class is often aggravated by a lack of cleanliness and poorly treated wounds and diseases. The cleanliness of a person's own body and home is particularly important. The handling of infectious diseases in one's own family is also addressed.

By now Anna has been going to the Red Falcon meetings regularly for over half a year. For the summer a large tent camp is planned under the title 'Children's Republic'. There, thousands of children will organise themselves for three weeks.

This of course costs a lot of money. In order to finance the Children's Republic, all local groups of the Kinderfreunde are busy collecting donations, selling symbolic building stones and even the smallest ones give away some of their pocket money.
The tent camp will take place on an uncultivated field near Kiel. Anna's local group has marked on a map the cities of the Weimar Republic from which children and youth groups have registered for it.
On the map you can see where the children come from.

content.value: Gerda has never organised the activities of a children's group before. To know her tasks better, she reads the book 'In the tent camp- a technical handbook for leaders of the Red Falcons' by Hermann Neddermayer. The book has just been published and collects valuable experiences from the previous camps of the Friends of the Children.

Gerda reads the pedagogical considerations inquisitively. In addition, there are also practical hints on the design of the tent village, the structure of the camp parliament and the organisational procedures in the Children's Republic. The helpers play a supporting, but not a leading role.
PH-B_279_Löwenstein_in_Seekamp_1927

In Leipzig, a training series is offered for the helpers. Gerda can thus familiarise herself with the socialist pedagogy of the Friends of the Children, because many things are new to her. She takes part in a weekend course entitled 'Psychology and socialist pedagogy as the basis of our youth work'. This course is led by Dr Kurt Löwenstein, the chairman of the 'National working-group of the Friends of the Children'.

groups.info: A horde refers to an undefined group of people - similar to a herd of animals.

content.value: In order to get practical training, Gerda also takes part in a training course on 'Methods of working in hordes'. 'Social hiking' is another such method, which is often used in groups (also called 'hordes'). Hiking is a way of exploring the world and foreign places and at the same time analysing the living and economic conditions of the local people.
Gerda sees this as a profound confrontation with another place. This method will therefore also be well suited to the Children's Republic.

The association has difficulties in finding volunteers, especially young helpers, who are willing to volunteer for longer periods of time. They often only help for a short time and then have more important things to do. Therefore, the association regularly organises activities exclusively for the volunteers, so that they get to know each other and experience the cohesion within the group of volunteers in addition to the responsible tasks.

Gerda takes part in a hike to which all helpers from her town are invited. In the end they are sixteen young people, all between 15 and 18 years old. Most of them will also be helpers in the Children's Republic. Gerda is looking forward to going there together with them.

One of these church representatives is a Catholic priest from the surrounding area. The Catholic Church in particular rejects the principle of coeducation propagated by the Friends of the Children. Coeducation means that girls and boys are active together in the group. The priest considers the shared tents in particular to be morally reprehensible.

He sees the children's turn towards socialism as a fight against religious education as well as a 'spiritual destruction of the family'. The Friends of the Children are also committed to sex education. They consider this to be important because until far into the 20th century, adults had no idea how children were created due to a misunderstood religious sexual morality.

Much of what the Friends of the Children tried out was new for society. The idea of a better world, in which children of workers would also have opportunities and a future, sometimes frightened those who had been in positions of power for centuries. These included the church, but also the nobility, for example.

Because they often cost four to five times the monthly wage of a worker. It was not until 1930 that affordable cameras became available - with larger roll films, but for only 40 Reichsmark.

Walter (a helper from Berlin) founded a photography course in his local group two years ago. Now he is the camp photographer in the Children's Republic.
He captures all the important moments: excursions, performances of the legendary camp circus, the food distribution, the music band and of course all other situations of group life.

Walter, together with some other children, is one of those responsible for the camp newspaper. Irma, Georg and Lotte regularly write short reports for the newspaper, which will later also serve as a souvenir of their time in the Children's Republic.
Irma's Report
content.title:
8th August
At 7 am the wake-up call came. Then we beat the dust out of our blankets. When we were done with it, gymnastics was announced. Shortly afterwards we went to the washing. After washing we had breakfast. Then we repaired our tent. Between 12 o'clock and 1 pm was the Falcon's general assembly. The new camp leader had different topics to negotiate, for example: the visiting day. We had a children's day and the helpers had nothing to say. They had to go on a hike instead. At 1.30 pm we got lunch. There were boiled potatoes with a rollmop. After lunch we had free time. At 3.30 pm we had a snack. After the snack time there was a circus. At 7 pm we had dinner. After that there was a folk dance. All of a sudden a noise had started in the street. The helpers came back from the hike. They were not supposed to get to the camp before 12 o'clock. Hermann Neddermeyer announced camp silence, but there were protests. Hermann told about his escape from England. Soon there was the camp rest. As soon as we were in the tents, the helper’s alarm sounded.
Friendship.
Irma

content.value: Georg's Report
content.title:
1st August
We were woken up this morning by the sound of the radio. Immediately afterwards Ernst, our mayor, came and brought today's slogan. After a while we got up, because it had blown to get out of bed. We quickly shook out our blankets. Then we went to wash ourselves. After coffee we stayed in the tent again, because it was raining. Heinz told us that we should 'pack our monkeys', because it could be that we would move into the emergency quarters today. Our camp president has already gone to town and asks if we could use some school as emergency quarters. So we packed our bags in the morning to be ready to leave and soon we had lunch. The weather was already getting better. In the evening there was a meeting for helpers. There, everything was discussed. It turned out that we were not going to move away today. But, if it continues to rain, we will move to the emergency quarters. In the evening we played in a circle. After the night's rest we soon fell asleep.
Friendship.
Georg

content.value: Lotte's Report
content.title:
23rd July
At 7 am the signal to get up was given. We got up immediately and shook out our blankets. Then we went straight to gymnastics. Frieda was in charge of gymnastics today. We got ready for washing right away, because we were the first ones today. After breakfast we could play. At 10.30 am we practised a movement choir with Willi. Then we had lunch. There were potatoes, mustard sauce and two eggs. After lunch we wanted to go hiking, but we had to vote first, because some did not want to join us. Finally, we started walking. We walked to the observation tower and picked blueberries. When it started to rain, we went back to the camp. We arrived late. Night's rest was at 9 pm.
Friendship.

content.value: The camp doctor is a real doctor and usually has a small practice in Bremen. Through his work he regularly sees how important fresh air, good nutrition and sport are for the workers' children. Therefore, he closes his practice for a few weeks in order to support the Children's Republic on a voluntary basis.
He cares for injured and sick children in the Children's Republic. Although every child should be medically examined before travelling, there are always cases of serious illness and epidemics.

Only last month there were reports of a smaller tent camp that was about to close. Several cases of the life-threatening disease diphtheria had occurred there. Fortunately, the affected children were quickly isolated and taken to hospital. The infection of other children was thus prevented.
The camp doctor regularly offers educational evenings on the subject of hygiene for the helpers. This knowledge is important so that diseases in the camp have no chance.

Nearly thirty children and young people stand in front of them with glowing torches in their hands. They shout something about 'socialist pigs' and 'traitors to the fatherland' and run away.

content.value: The most important point for the Falcons is the commitment to the working class and to a socialist society.

This meant that the Friends of the Children as well as the Social Democratic Party and the German Communist Party were confronted with a growing political movement: the National Socialist German Workers' Party (NSDAP) was making the same effort to court the favour of the workers.

In contrast to Socialism, however, National Socialism did not stand for peaceful coexistence of all people, but for racism and exclusion of people, especially of the Jewish faith, and the strengthening of the so-called 'people's community', which meant a racially unified society. In this way, National Socialism promoted war between different countries.
Since 1926 there had already been a youth organisation of the NSDAP, the Hitler Youth, which was just as attractive for children as the socialist and social democratic associations.

Anna can hardly believe that so many children and young people are gathered in one place here in the Children's Republic. It gives her great pleasure to meet new children every day, even if this sometimes has its difficulties.
30_Anna_Dialekte
Even if the children sometimes talk at cross purposes and use different words, there is one thing they all understand and like equally well: cinema.

In the afternoon, the helpers organised a film screening for the young republicans in a nearby cinema. In two shifts all children watch a silent movie by Buster Keaton. No words are needed for this, because everyone understands this humour.
Usually, excursions and working groups take place before lunch.
The quieter afternoons can be filled by the children themselves to pursue their interests. Many then spend the time reading and writing letters.
However, group matters sometimes need to be clarified during this time. The children also call this time 'tear-hair-hour' because there are often lively discussions.
Every now and then, the volunteers give natural history lectures in the individual tent villages. This helps the children learn about the animals and plants in the area.
Some afternoons the whole camp moves! The children then learn folk dances from all parts of the republic and even from other countries. They dance all together: Boys and girls.
In the evenings there are sometimes cultural events and singsongs.
Almost all matters are decided democratically. Nevertheless, there are sometimes situations in which this is of no use, because...

However, there is also literature that is intended to strengthen the children's intellectual and moral attitude. Alongside important works by socialist authors, there is also highly topical anti-war literature, e.g. 'All Quiet on the Western Front' by Erich Maria Remarque.

content.value: In Anna's and Karl's tent village, several children have come together to make a request to the camp parliament. They want to ensure that gymnastics takes place in the morning after breakfast and not before.

After receiving majority support for this proposal in their tent community, they submit the proposal to the tent village council.

The tent village council consists of fifteen children and the mayor. Before the vote, the mayor points out that sport with a full stomach is unhealthy. Nevertheless, the majority of the tent village council agrees to the motion, because the time until breakfast is often too long for the children.

The mayor must now pass the proposal on to the camp parliament so that all representatives of the tent village councils can discuss and vote on it. In the end, the camp parliament rejects the proposal with a large majority.

It justifies its decision with the fact that the kitchen staff needs some time after getting up to prepare the meal and that sport before the meal is healthier than directly after.
Anna realised that the process is really complicated. In order to better explain the whole camp structure, she made up a game. She plays it with Karl to see if it is understandable.
In this game, the aim is to find identical pairs. Just click on the cards to see what is on the back. Matching pairs remain face up.

content.value: Gerda has watched the two children play and thinks Anna's idea is great. She wants to try out the game with her local group when they prepare for the next camp.

Since Gerda is only a few years older than Anna and Karl, she has a good connection to them. They listen eagerly as she tells them how she came to the Socialist Workers' Youth and why she became a helper in the Children's Republic.
Maybe in a few years Anna and Karl will want to help out in a Children's Republic. After all, they have already gained enough experience.
28_Deutschfranzösisches_Zeltlager
Until then, however, they plan to take part in one of the next Workers' Youth Days. This takes place every one or two years and is expected to be held in Frankfurt am Main in 1931.
Working-class children from all over the Weimar Republic meet there, express their solidarity and make plans for a better future.
The Children's Republic is slowly coming to an end. For Anna and Karl, this time has flown by.
They have made many new friends. Many of them, as the two of them, will soon start an apprenticeship in one of the big factories.
Anna and Karl hope that they will perhaps write letters to each other, if they can still find the time and energy to do so after work. They would also like to write to Gerda.

But at least Karl and Anna no longer feel so alone, because they now know that there are many children and young people who are in a similar situation as they are. And they all hope for a better future for themselves and their families.

content.value: Many of the children and young people who took part in camps of the Friends of the Children and the Socialist Workers' Youth in the 1920s and 1930s were persecuted, imprisoned and also murdered for their political commitment after 1933.
The images used here often survived only by chance or because they had been well hidden and kept like a treasure.
